1.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
1.title: "At Least He Gets His Off the Ground"
1.author: Amend.
notes: Summary: Paige compares Jason's kite flying to that of Charlie Brown in the Peanuts strip.

2.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
2.title: "Charlie Brown in Indian Country"
2.author: Larson.
notes: Summary: Charlie Brown is buried to his neck in the desert, and a vulture is watching him.

3.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
3.title: "Cracker Jacks. Who Draws That?"
3.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: The women think of selling Peanuts and Cracker Jacks during the baseball games.

4.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
4.title: "Desi and Lucy"
4.author: Mike Peters.
notes: Summary: Desi Arnaz is drumming, and Lucy Van Pelt is thinking, "Good grief."

5.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
5.title: "Everything from this Bösendorfer Nine-Foot Concert Grand, on Down"
5.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Arlo is shopping for a piano, and the salesman seems to be a grown-up Schroeder from the Peanuts strip.

6.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
6.title: "Gesundheit"
6.author: Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: A Bugs Bunny Pez dispenser has just sneezed candy all over a Snoopy Pez dispenser.

7.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
7.title: "Good Grief! This Could Be a Long Season!"
7.author: Scrawls ; apologies to Charlie Schulz.
notes: Summary: Charlie Brown shows up for Pops' football team.

8.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
8.title: "I Know Where You Saw It and I'm Not Falling For It"
8.author: Stantis.
notes: Summary: A boy is holding a football to be kicked, like Lucy does in Peanuts.

9.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
9.title: "I Think It's Meat Loaf"
9.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Schroeder remembers to tell Arlo that he gets a free bust if he buys a piano.
Key words: Peanuts, incentives.

10.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
10.title: "It Was Thought to Be Too Derivative"
10.author: G
notes: Summary: Glimpse of an early version of Doonesbury shows Zonker in Charlie Brown's clothes on his back on top of a doghouse.

11.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
11.title: "Life Without Peanuts"
11.author: Guisewite.
notes: Summary: Cathy reacts to the ending of the Peanuts comic strip.

12.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
12.title: "A Little Something by Vince Guaraldi"
12.author: by Jimmy Johnson.
notes: Summary: Arlo listens to Schroeder demonstrate a piano, complete with notes over his head, and asks if it's Beethoven.
Key words: Peanuts, salesmen.

13.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
13.title: "The Pussycat Lounge?"
13.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Arlo can't get over how familiar Schroeder looks, but apparently hasn't seen him at the art-museum brunch.
Key words: Peanuts, pianists.

14.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
14.title: "She's a Psychologist"
14.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Schroeder describes his career as a pianist and baseball player (minor league catcher), and the love of a strong woman that gave him direction.
Allusions are to Peanuts, and Lucy Van Pelt.

15.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
15.title: "That's When I Knew I Had To Quit The Jazz Scene"
15.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Schroeder talks about seeing notes in the air over his head, except on one gig they turned to little yellow birds.
Key words: Peanuts, Woodstock, pianists.

16.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
16.title: "Today's the Last Day of Peanuts, So You've Dressed Up like Pig Pen!"
16.author: by Bill Amend.
notes: Summary: Actually Jason blew up the vacuum cleaner.

17.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
17.title: "What Do You Care Who Wrote It?"
17.author: Johnson.
notes: Summary: Arlo is reading to his cat, apparently from Snoopy's novel: "It was a dark and stormy night. Suddenly a shot rang out!"

18.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
18.title: "What's With All the Lettering on Your Wall?"
18.author: Jim Meddick.
notes: Summary: He wishes he was in some simple comic strip like Peanuts, Garfield, or Beetle Bailey.

19.heading: Peanuts--Allusions and Mentions.
19.title: "Would You Mind Jamming It Into My Neck?"
19.author: Mark Parisi.
notes: Summary: A Pez dispenser in the form of Charlie Brown from Peanuts, asks the waiter's help with his meal.

29.heading: Peanuts--Articles About.
29.title: "Reining In the Parade"

29.appears_in: C. Harvey. p. 99-103 in The Comics Journal, no. 221 (Mar. 2000).

Essay on the continuing of comic strips after the death of their creators, with special attention to Peanuts and Pogo, and paragraphs on the situations with Bringing Up Father, Blondie, Gasoline Alley, Barnaby, Popeye, Out Our Way (The Willets), Snuffy Smith (Barney Google), Moon Mullins, and Annie (Little Orphan Annie).

Summary (from OCLC): A portrait of the late creator of the "Peanuts" comic strip evaluates how his career was shaped by his midwestern working-class origins, family losses, and wartime experiences, offering insight into how familiar storylines closely reflected Schulz's private life.

81.heading: Peanuts--Miscellanea.
81.title: The History of the Comics [videorecording]
81.author: EPISA (Euskal Pictures International, S
81.appears_in: A.) ; co-production, ETB (Euskal Telebista) ; The Department of Culture of the Basque government ; with support from the Spanish Ministry of Culture ; producer, Iñigo Silva ; director, Alejandro Vallejo ; script, Carmen Dominguez, Alejandro Vallejo.
notes: 4 VHS videocassettes (ca. 360 min.) : sd., col. and b&w ; 1/2 in.

Summary: Four-part series on the history of comics. Volume 1 follows the beginnings of comics and some of the comic book characters that were popular during the turn of the century, World War I, the Roaring '20s and the Great Depression. Volume 2 deals with the superheroes and characters with superhuman powers that are still popular today, just as they were 40 and 50 years ago. It also discusses how the 1950s and 1960s inspired the creation of a whole new cast of comic characters for a baby boom generation. Volume 3 looks at the underground movement of the 1960s and the alternative-style comics it produced that ferociously attacked society. It also discusses the superheroes of the 1970s and 1980s and the impact of the Punk movement on comics. Volume 4 wraps up the series with the new changes in comics, from superheroes who are becoming more human to dealing with ecological disasters and drugs. The program also looks at the future of comics and features today's young artists and writers.
Contents v 1: The Katzenjammer kids ; Betty Boop ; Little Orphan Annie ; Popeye ; Tarzan ; Gasoline Alley ; Dick Tracy ; Flash Gordon ; The Phantom.
v. 2: Superman ; Batman ; Steve Canyon ; Peanuts ; Captain America ; James Bond ; Beetle Bailey ; Mad ; Andy Capp.
v. 3: Vampirella ; Conan ; Furry Freak Brothers ; Spider-Man ; Little Annie Fanny ; Incredible Hulk ; Fantastic Four ; Creepy magazine ; Judge Dredd.
v. 4: X-Men ; Outland ; Heavy Metal ; Green Arrow ; Watchmen ; Atom ; Elf Quest ; Ronin ; Green Lantern.
